awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Novel Slurry Injector Device for Chemical Mechanical Planarization Application
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project aims to develop a novel slurry injection device for applications in chemical mechanical planarization (CMP), a key technology for integrated circuit (IC) manufacturing. Different from the current slurry application method that applies slurry on the pad center area during wafer polishing, this novel slurry injector device is placed on top of the pad surface, injects the fresh slurry to where it is needed, and reduces slurry mixing and dilution effects by blocking used slurry, pad debris, and rinsing water from re-entering the pad-wafer interface. Tests will be performed on various polishers to optimize the slurry injector device design for different CMP processes.  This slurry injector device is expected to achieve higher material removal rates and reduce polishing defects compared to current pad center area slurry application method.  

The broader/commercial impacts of this project will be the potential to reduce slurry consumption and increase yield during CMP processes for the IC manufacturing industry. In 2012, the global point-of-use slurry usage is estimated to be in excess of 600 million liters corresponding to a total slurry expenditure of approximately $1 billion. Assuming a conservative slurry savings of 15 percent by this slurry injector device, it represents a potential $150 million savings in slurry and an additional $25 million savings in waste treatment.

Currently, chemical mechanical planarization (CMP) is widely used in the integrated circuit (IC) manufacturing industry to achieve both local (on the micrometer scale) and global (on the millimeter scale) surface planarity. During CMP processes, the over-deposited materials from elevated features on a wafer surface are removed to achieve planarization through the synergistic work of chemical and mechanical actions. During the process, a slurry containing nano abrasive particles is injected onto a polishing pad. A rotating wafer is controllably pressed down against the co-rotating pad. As the slurry enters the pad-wafer interface, it chemically reacts with the wafer to form a softened surface layer. With the wafer being pressed down and rotating against the pad, the softened wafer surface layer is then mechanically removed by the frictional force generated among the wafer, slurry abrasive particles, and pad.

 

Compared with other unit processes used in IC manufacturing, CMP is associated with a large cost of ownership (COO) due to consumables (i.e. slurries, pads and diamond discs) used in the processes. Among the consumables used in CMP processes, slurries may account for up to 50% of the total cost. In addition, slurry consumption has tremendous environmental impacts as spent slurries can contain hazardous chemicals and metal contents with large amounts of nano abrasive particles after polishing.

 

For most current CMP commercial polishers, slurry is injected on the pad center area. Pads with different groove designs are used by different IC makers to help transport the slurry to the pad-wafer interface. As the pad rotates during polishing, a large amount of fresh slurry flows directly off the pad surface without entering the pad-wafer interface due to the centrifugal force. This results in very low slurry utilization. On the other hand, some spent slurry stays on the pad surface, mixes with the fresh slurry, and then re-enters the pad-wafer interface. As the spent slurry contains polishing by-products, it may decrease material removal rate and cause polishing defects. If in-situ pad conditioning is used during wafer polishing, the spent slurry will contain pad debris generated by the conditioning process, which has been shown to cause polishing defects. As polishing by-products and pad debris are generated on the pad surface, a large amount of deionized (DI) water is used to rinse them off the pad surface between wafer polishing. This is referred to as the pad rinsing step. At the end of this rinsing step, there is an appreciable amount of DI water staying on the pad surface and inside the pad grooves. When the fresh slurry is injected onto the pad surface to polish the next wafer, the fresh slurry will mix with the residue DI water and get diluted, resulting in a lower material removal. In summary, the current pad center area slurry injection method does not provide efficient slurry utilization and leaves significant room for polishing performance (material removal rate and defects) improvement.

 

The innovation of this project is to develop and implement a novel slurry injection device in commercial CMP processes. Through this novel slurry injection device, fresh slurry can be efficiently delivered to the pad-wafer interface and react with the wafer surface. In addition, the novel slurry injection device is placed on top of the pad surface during polishing to reduce mixing of spent slurry and residue rinsing DI water with the fresh slurry on the pad surface and in the pad-wafer interface. Through more efficient slurry delivery and reduced slurry mixing and dilution effects, the novel slurry injection device can achieve higher material removal rates and fewer polishing defects with significantly lower slurry consumption.
